content.description: Start out with your hands on some tiny but not bad holds and a good lip for your feet. Send up right with your right hand to a juggy sidepull, then send your left foot straight up and your right foot out right, and do a second dyno towards a big shelf - a very good hold. From there, pull up into a second shelf, match your hands, and descend.
content.location: It is very early on the wall, on the left side. The large holds are obvious - both have defined points aiming right.

content.description: Do a low start on a jug in a big crack, bump up right to a crimp, then move up left to another, bring your right hand to match, your left hand goes straight to the side to another crimp, and your right hand comes next to it. Do tricky footwork and one big or two small moves to another jug in a mossy crack to top out.
content.location: It is dead center of the wall and climbs a big crack with a jug right in the middle and uses a low shelf for starting feet. The crimps are a little sneaky to spot, and the finish is out left in a big, obvious crack.

content.description: Do the same start as Happy Chick, Subtle Traverse, and Extra Mayo, but this time it's straight up. Send up into the first two crimps on Subtle Traverse, then go up with your left hand into a sidepull in a finger crack, then move out right into a slopey sidepull. Shuffle up with your feet wide and hands pulling towards one another. Get high foot holds onto two jugs from in one fluid compression move, then move up left along a little rail with a fun pinch, and top out around left of the boulder sitting on top of the crag. Use the tree to top out if you need it.
content.protection: A crashpad, and there's an anchor as the top on some webbing that you can use to help with the topout.
content.location: The dead center, obvious crack follows the line. Then top out left of the boulder that sits on top of this wall.

content.description: Do the same start as the Subtle Traverse, but this time go straight to the right with a layback on some good holds, then slap a sloper with your right, pull a heel hook onto the edge you've been laying back on, send your left hand up and to the right into a good crack, find your feet, match the crack, and top out up and to the right onto a dirt covered shelf.
content.location: Use the same start as Subtle Traverse with a very obvious rail to follow to the right, then climb a well defined crack and spot to top out.

content.description: Start off with Happy Chick, then to put on a little extra mayo, go straight up from the crack section instead of finishing out right. Go into a fun, little slab problem with some tiny edges and a good compression move, bust up into some more little edges, wedge your hand in a huge crack under a boulder up top, and top out over the wall.
content.location: Use the same start as Subtle Traverse and same opening sequence as Happy Chick. There is a notably bare slab section on the second half.

content.description: *[DISCLAIMER]* DO NOT GO INTO THIS AREA YET. AWAITING PERMISSION TO FURTHER DEVELOP SO WE DONT INFRINGE ON LAND ACCESS LIMITATIONS AND PROPERTY OWNERS Clark Crag is a small wall off of the Stone Bench Trail system that covers the land behind the Clark Art Museum in Williamstown, MA. This features fun boulder problems with a range of crimps, slopers, cracks, and jugs. It is an awesome training ground and an excellent spot for an afternoon off work or to grab a few laps in between classes.
